reviewText: Well I wasn't expecting something awesome, but after half hour my interest changed into bitterness. A lots of classes is what I really liked about this game. A different options of game style can keep you even in most boring games for a long period of time. But after I discovered how the dice works the fate of this game was forever sealed for me. You will mostly get 1 to 3 on normal rolls and when you roll 1 next roll will be 4. When you roll 2 next roll wil be 5 and same with 3 and 6. The problem is that mostly your opponent gets those good rolls and until you use fate you are screwed. Besides of the evil dice you get a lot of bugs like getting stuck after spell failure because you press some key on the keyboard and there is nothing you can do except for quiting the game. Your raft won't work, your items and so on ... and I experienced this in about 2 hours ... so you can make a picture.

reviewText:
I'm a longtime fan of this game, as I've had the actual boardgame itself for years. This digital version gives me a great way to play with buddies who I'm not physically around anymore, which is great.

I played through one game already and it seems to work fine. There does seem to be one bug with the thief, though: when at the crown of command with another character, he still had the opportunity to steal, despite his character card saying he needed to LAND on the character's space in order to steal from them. Not sure if that was an interpretation thing, an error, or some kind of bug in the code, but thought it was worth mentioning.

overall, though, just like the boardgame. Definitely a recommendation for anyone who has friends long distances away that they like playing talisman with, as well as anyone who just loves boardgame type games period.

reviewText:
In the end, Talisman: Digital Edition is a faithful recreation of the classic board game, from what I've heard.  If you’ve played Talisman on a board or are a fan of tabletop RPGs, odds are you’ll have a blast playing with people from all over the world (or the AI) and I easily recommend purchasing it.  If you aren’t a fan of tabletop or haven’t played it, be aware that Talisman: Digital Edition is not like your typical videogame.  It’s more akin to a board game, and therefore is a sort of niche title.  I’d recommend at least trying it through Steam’s Family Share if possible, or watch extended gameplay trailers to get an idea of what to expect.  I've never played the original board game, so I can't really compare the two.  But for the most part, I found this to be a really enjoyable game.  Even more so as I am an avid boardgamer as well, so now I'll have to find a copy of the physical version later on.

As an added bonus, what makes this version of the game stand out against its real-life counterpart is the player progression scheme.  After you beat the game (or even lose it), you earn experience points based on your performance and are rewarded with Runestones and Steam Achievements.  There are fifty achievements on Steam and you can equip your next hero with up to three Runestones which can affect everything from starting lives to not missing a turn when your hero drinks too much in the tavern!  This progression will keep you coming back for more play sessions as you try to accomplish something you didn’t earn in your last play-through.

A really great game if you're into these types of games.

reviewText:
For those who can't get to an actual table often (or at all) this is a great alternative to play Talisman.  Don't know what it is?  Think Fantasy Monopoly and you sort of have the idea, only instead of buying properties and gathering cash and boning your friends, you're fighting monsters, gathering treasure, gambling money, and... well, boning your friends.  It's an all-time classic board game.

Only downside is they charge about the same amount for the DLC as they do for the real game's expansions, so if you actually can get a good regular gaming group together, getting the actual game is probably a much better course of action for you.

Note: as of this writing, the DLC list has shrunk down to three, so the above comment may no longer be valid, but during the Early Access, you could see listed all the expansions for the physical game at the same price.  This may turn up later.

EDIT: Don't know why my play counter is 0.  I've definitely played this a helluvalot more than that.

reviewText:
Incredibly fun and infuriating at the same time.  Requires more than 1 play through for you to really appreciate the game, and while the game is heavily luck dependant, there is strategy in managing your resources and coming up with plans to try and succeed from almost all points of the game.  You could be 2 turns from being the winner and then fnd yourself turned toad if youve wasted all your resources getting to where you are.  Two good bonuses to the already good game are that

1) The bots are very well made and provide an excellent alternative for when you dont have friends to play with or cant find an open game online
2) With the exception of the specific character DLC, as long as the host of a game owns a content DLC, players without the DLC can still join and play with the content (they still wont be able to use the DLC characters however)

reviewText:
There's no satisfaction in winning or losing as the entire game (except for the spells aspect) is based 100% on luck. I'd never thought I'd find a game based more on luck than Monopoly, but here it is. If you like to strategize then this game is not for you, your ability to reach the end and win is purely determined by dice rolls and luck of draw cards (all dice rolls are pre-calculated before the game starts).

No strategy will overcome events like being turned into a toad 7 times within 8 turns (yes this did happen) or losing a fight with a 60/50 chance of winning 13 times in a row (yes this happened too).

Talisman is really just a dice simulator with music and ren fair style graphics, and just ended up in my uninstall pile.

reviewText:
After other players managed to convince me the constant crashes are due to a recent expansion and the Devs are usually on top of it with fixes, I realised that it was the hand of fate that made me start this game in the middle of utter chaos.

Thus, on the basis of the game alone, I give it my thumbs up
(changed from negative).

Yes, the game itself, when not crashing, is fun.
Well, for people with stamina and patience and time for a bit of commitment it is fun,
for people that like the intimacy of boardgames it is fun,
I do not recommend it for impatient kids that can't sit still for 15 minutes, because fun will not be had.

Is it worth the money the expansion sets cost?
That is something everyone needs to decide for themselves, in comparison I'd say it's not too steep
(although I'm tight enough to have weighed these words before typing them).
All in all, (and I'm liking it more every time I play a game without crashing),
I give the game a careful 6.7 out of 10.

Please take my playing time into account, which isn't very long, check the reviews of those who have been playing it for longer, or you know, take the plunge!

Greetings fellow travellores and connaisseurs of Trollplaying games (TPG's)

reviewText:
I spent 10 hours playing 2 matches (versus 3x AI, at speed 4).

Cons:
-There are meaningful decisions to be made, but they are dwarfed by RNG.
-It therefore follows that hours of building up can be undone in seconds.
-Once a player makes it to the Crown, it seems there is little that can be done.
-Matches take a very long time if you see them all the way through.
-Clunky magic system. It would be much better if every player was asked to pass, rather than give 5 seconds to cast.
-Bit buggy? Sometimes mechanics are not applied [correctly]?

Pros:
-...I spent 10 hours playing 2 matches. Clearly, despite the cons, this is just fun for me on some bizarre, torturous level!

reviewText:
Bought a four pack for my friends and me for 4€ not expecting much, we were simply blown away after 2 games and have at least played 5 rounds for every week since the initial purchase.

I highly recommend buying the season pass (includes all future expansions and characters except the shaman, which i glady payed for since the money spent is given to a charity) to add more depth to the otherwise limited standard game.

Pros:
- ideal game for four people
- beautiful visual presentation of the original board game
- the game never gets boring (even after 136h)
- lots of different characters with different abilities and properties (for starters i recommend randomizing your char pick)
- multiple endings

minor cons:
- avoid playing on a weekend where the game is free to play (seriously it is unplayable in mp)
- the spell system could use a little overhaul
- more game options ( for example choosing which endings can occur and which can not)

Overall i would give this game a 9.9 of 10

reviewText: I used to play this game often with my old roomates twenty years ago. This is an amazing adaptation. The graphics are awesome and faithfully reproduce the board. It would really be nice if other board games could make the digital transition like this one. My only real complaint is that the AI seemed like it was cheating since it would regularily get the rolls it needed to win some unlikely battles or land on a coveted card. I found myself using an exploit to get around the questionable rolls but recently it was updated and the exploit no longer works. The new update seems to generate a dice table the same way many other digital dice games do. I got the season pass for this one also and have been loving all the DLC. The Dungeon is pretty cool. If you liked the original board game then this one is a must. Its easy to loose many hours here.

reviewText:
I got a copy of the boardgame back in the 80s and I loved it.  Now this is a true representation of the game complete with identical adventure cards (etc) - although Fate's a new one on me.  I also picked up the Dungeon expansion to make my nostalgia complete.

So why the bad review?  It's clunky mess with the interface not being all that intuitive.  Forever clicking the mouse button to speed up some animation only to pause the game.  It just doesn't gel which is a real shame.

If you're a fan of the boardgame and can sit through a clunky UI then it's a non-brainer; if you've never played the boardgame don't go near this unless you know you're going to be online with friends.

reviewText:
Incredibly fun and infuriating at the same time.  Requires more than 1 play through for you to really appreciate the game, and while the game is heavily luck dependant, there is strategy in managing your resources and coming up with plans to try and succeed from almost all points of the game.  You could be 2 turns from being the winner and then fnd yourself turned toad if youve wasted all your resources getting to where you are.  Two good bonuses to the already good game are that

1) The bots are very well made and provide an excellent alternative for when you dont have friends to play with or cant find an open game online
2) With the exception of the specific character DLC, as long as the host of a game owns a content DLC, players without the DLC can still join and play with the content (they still wont be able to use the DLC characters however)

reviewText:
Pros:

- it sticks to the original board game (figures and cards)
- requires some tactical thinking
- nice soundtrack
- each game is different!
- characters from the additions (AND additions themselves!)
- many achievements to accomplish

Cons:

- a bit too much randomness
- bugs and crashes (thankfully they still improve this)
- not so smart bots
- the music becomes repetitive after some time

I'm a big fan of the original board game and I'm not dissapointed. Of course nothing beats the atmosphere of sitting with friends around the table and rolling dice by your own hands but, from the other hand, you can compete with other Talisman lovers from the whole world!

9/10

reviewText:
For those who can't get to an actual table often (or at all) this is a great alternative to play Talisman.  Don't know what it is?  Think Fantasy Monopoly and you sort of have the idea, only instead of buying properties and gathering cash and boning your friends, you're fighting monsters, gathering treasure, gambling money, and... well, boning your friends.  It's an all-time classic board game.

Only downside is they charge about the same amount for the DLC as they do for the real game's expansions, so if you actually can get a good regular gaming group together, getting the actual game is probably a much better course of action for you.

Note: as of this writing, the DLC list has shrunk down to three, so the above comment may no longer be valid, but during the Early Access, you could see listed all the expansions for the physical game at the same price.  This may turn up later.

EDIT: Don't know why my play counter is 0.  I've definitely played this a helluvalot more than that.

reviewText:
I've never played Talisman before and would probably never get a chance in my country, so digital versions do come in handy. I've played a few matches and although game is complex (great), rich and detailed (excellent) and full of amazing details and additional content (nice, nice, supernice), I've always had a feeling I am being cheated out of dice rolls. Even compared to Chainsaw Warrior, card game that really snuffs out the players 9 out of 10 times, this game always felt way too artificial under the colorful hood.

Well now...

I've uninstalled the game and reinstalled it today when I saw there's a Humble Bundle package with some additional content available for a low price. I was just about to buy and indulge in playing muted Talisman and listening to audiobook again when a buddy of mine made me read a shocking post by a developer himself.

That post is available at Steam's community hub for Talisman: Digital Edition and it explains in detail the horrid decision of game devs that I really don't understand at all.

The most important part is this one and no, it's not taken out of context:

At the start of a new game
date: a huge list of random numbers between 1 and 6 is generated. That list of numbers is used for the whole game
recommended: in the order that they are determined at this point."\n\nI understand it this way - in the game based on factor of random dice rolls
hoursPlayed: you get a predetermined row of numbers which influence your moves. There are no true random dice rolls
voteText: no luck. Only a rigging generator.\n\nThis decision truly crushes my enthusiasm to play this game any longer and to buy any new content. I am sorry
helpfulPercent: but I don't see any point of dice rolling when my game is (almost completely) predetermined. When I buy a game that relies on dice rolls
votesHelpful: I want random dice rolls. There's no excuse for this sad state of affairs and although I never do this
votesTotal: I urge you all to vote this review up so people prove to the devs changes have to be made to make a great game - great."

reviewText: A  fun and entertaining game, however the AI is complete and utter, bull. I can not stress this idea enough. I spent half an hour trying to kill the only remaining Swashbuckler in a 1 vs. 5 AI game. He would not simply die. What i mean by this, is that he would honestly get down to 1 life point remaining and then miraculously roll the die into the perfect number to land on a square in which he could heal. The game finally ended when the AI moved him into the most inner ring where he had no methods of self healing.\n\nOverall it's a great game and lives up to the experiences i've had through the actual irl gameboard. However this game requires a lot of patience. I don't reccommend this game if you don't like waiting forever to end the game. (If the turns are slow, you can fix that in the advaced settings.)

reviewText: I used to play the tabletop version of this many moons ago when I was a wee lad. I don't know if you can still buy them, but back then you could get, like, a dozen expansions that came with additional game boards like a dungeon and one that allowed you to travel through space. My brother and I liked playing the expansions more than the vanilla game because every expansion added these wicked overpowered new characters and objects and instead of the usual gameplay strat of just travel around the outer region for a half an hour to level up before going towards the middle" it became "bum rush the space lanes to get the laser rifle and the anti-grav belt and spend the next fifteen minutes griefing the other players until they get mad and give up".\n\nDad says: If you like this kind of nerd ♥♥♥♥

reviewText:
There are alot of things done good in this game: They didn't change the rules or the cards, the graphics is good, the AI's play reasonably good. This is a good didgital rendering of a fantastic board-game.
The problem is the pace.

In Real-life board game your opponents are human. You have fun sitting around the table passing time and gaming. But when playing against AIs waiting isn't fun. It's annoying and tiresome.
And the AI in this game thinks SLOWLY. VERY VERY SLOWLY. Even on maximum speed.
And the graphics. Oh the graphics. It's good. Really. But SLOW. SO SO SLOW. The well intended animation of everything from rolling a die to the turn shifting to the next player makes the turns unbearably long. So long infact I got up made popcorn, and came back to find it's still isn't my turn.
So slow I find myself incapable of playing the game without doing atleast one more thing.

This game would have been a 9/10 if you had a No animation" option. Without it the pace of the game is so slow I'm compeled to give it a 3/10 - Nice try."

reviewText:
I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game. Whilst I have many fond memories of Talisman from my childhood, this is a terrible implementation of a game that has long past exceeded its best-by date.

Talisman itself is sadly lacking in the current era of boardgames, with little to no strategy or choice left to the player. It is dictated far more by the random roll of the die, than any particular desire of the player. Even Monopoly provides more strategy, and choice of action. This is a faithful implementation of the original, for what little that is worth.

The main issue is the interface, which is an abomination. Trying to play with friends rapidly becomes an excercise in extreme frustration, wherein you battle the shoddy controls - instead of battling your friends. Laggy, unresponsive and unintuitive are the nicest words I have to say about it. I wish I could refund it, and I feel terrible for gifting it to several of my friends who now all have a much poorer opinion of me.

If you have any fondness for Talisman, any decent memories of the game - leave them as that, memories. Playing this game will leave only a bitter taste in your mouth of ashes and defeat. Nomad Games has my money - please dont give them yours.

reviewText:
You'll have already read what the game is: a faithful recreation of a board-game classic with high fidelity to the original, a somewhat sketchy interface, a few bugs, and the same glacial pacing as if you were playing around a table, minus the board setup.

AI is one of the keys to transition between in-person and computer-based play. The programmers haven't solved that problem well at all. Computer opponents don't have much strategy besides accumulating stats and items. They perform like mediocre bots in the single-player training missions of an online FPS. A human player would wipe the table with them every time, except the AI appears to get a boost via favorable die rolls and card draws, likely to disguise its lack of real strategy. The first few games this doesn't matter much, but after dozens of games it sucks the enjoyment out of it.

If you have 3 friends willing to play the game with you, I'd buy this game in a heartbeat. If you're going to fill in with computer players--and especially if you just want to play single-player--this is probably a pass.

For that reason--plus constant problems connecting with servers resulting in interrupted games--I have to give this game a no vote even though I generally like it. It's not a horrible purchase, just know what you're getting into.

reviewText:
There is a lot to be said about the charm of nostelgia... but not enough to deflect the idea that time can be cruel and that some things, like Talisman, do not age well.

This game is quite a nice digital version of a boardgame from long ago, but as such it does not have the benefits granted from all the game development that would come after it.
That is not meant to be a cruel jab, if anything is is an apology for why I can't find much positive to say.

All you really need to know is that this game is an excercise in being given a very small set (usually 2) of options each turn based on the roll of a die. those options are then resolved throught the roll of another die... and then that loop is repeated for about an hour or more with plenty of long pauses taken at random intervals.
Your input into this game is so small, and the luck so great that it is hard to truely feel that this game needs you to be present, or that any sucess or failure is yours to claim.

The translation from cardboard to digital is well done and smooth in most places, but does have a few flaws, (there is no option to hide all of the A.I.'s desicion making if you are playing with bots, and it can only be sped up so much in the options... meaning that your already drawn out experiance is now stretched further and thinner.)

It can be applauded for being such a faithful replication of a board game, but as to wether that excersice is, itself, worthwhile, my feelings lead towards: No.

If you are an old board gamer who maybe missed out on this little bit of gaming history and wanted to experiance it, this is a good way to do so, but if you are anyone else, there are better digital board games, much better non-digital board games, and infinitely better digital adventure simulators.

Try any of them before this.

reviewText: I have been playing this game for about 6 months now, and I've finally had it with this game. This game is FULL of bugs. The game will routinely change the rules on you and outright cheat to help the AI and screw over players. That isn't even the part that bothers me though. The game has had a problem with crashing and lost connections since I started playing, but it is now to a point where I can't go more than 2 minutes without getting kicked from a game. Even if I rejoin the game each time, the program will eventually crash and I am forced to close the game. This is not just my experience - all of my friends experience the same thing, and a quick search online shows that many people are fed up with these same problems. Do not even waste your time buying this game, the devs don't care about fixing the MASSIVE issues that make this game wholly unplayable. For how long this game has been on the market, there is no excuse for this. The devs should be ashamed and either FIX THE PROBLEMS or get this game off the market.

reviewText:
I picked this game up for $5.  At that price, you really can't go that wrong.  That being said, this game really walks the line between whether or not to give it a positive or a negative review overall.

The design flaws of the Talisman game really manifest itself when you play with a rigid, impassionate interpreter of the game.   This doesn't seem like a bad thing, but Talisman has evolved over the years with very little consistency: there's a huge variety of nuances in the language used.  Phrases such as ...at any time..." implies a different expectation than what is actually practiced in the game.

The honest truth is
date: people zone out when they play Talisman.  You miss a few turns in jail
recommended: or wait for four other players to battle dragons
voteText: and ponder over quests; just so you can roll a 3 and scoop up a bag of gold.  There's a whole layer missing from the electronic version of the game that you get when you are playing on the tabletop with your friends that really is the only thing that makes Talisman an acceptable use of an afterrnoon.\n\nThe game would also benefit from an ability to remove specific cards from out of the deck; because there are some really grossly imbalanced combinations as well as cards you just get sick of seeing- like the one that takes all the face up city cards and put them on top of the adventure deck.  The electronic version of the game also takes longer to play
helpfulPercent: as every step of the game is iterated out individually.  The dice roller seems very suspect as well.  I've had back to back snake eyes when dicing with death as well as +3 Craft from the Reaper in three stops.\n\nThe game does give you something to do while your waiting in a que or auto-running to your next mission
votesHelpful: but it's hard to recommend solely on the experience it offers.  To be honest
votesTotal: considering how horribly overpriced the Fantasy Flight version of the game is
votesFunny: I would still recommend this version of the game over the table top version.  I'm sticking with my 2nd Edition Games Workshop version."

reviewText:
Unless you're a huge fan of the original board game you might want to give this a pass.

On the surface it's fine. There's a board. There are cards, characters and a die. Great.

Unfortunately once you actually start to play you realize pretty quickly that you're dealing with a tablet port that's had oodles of time put into it on the dlc-front, but not so much on  the optimizing-for-pc front. There's the base game, then several expansions, then I don't even know how many characters for a buck or three apiece, and there ain't a thing wrong with any of that assuming the game plays well and stable on the average pc.

That's where things begin to break down. There's a very long-standing and unresolved bug affecting a lot of people wherein if you afk from the game for anything more than about 60 seconds or so you'll return to a frozen screen, which you can only fix" by force-closing the game in Task Manager and restarting. There's thread after thread after report after report on the Discussions page

reviewText:
Do not buy unless it is on sale for $1.
Talisman is one of the best board games that have ever come out. However, I am talking about the original board game, not the digital edition. I am not going to describe the single player feature as it is very poor and AI does not demand any thinking from the player, making the single player game easy, boring and discouraging. Therefore, I will concetrate on the multiplayer feature since it is the only feature worth looking at.

The rules are very simple: roll a dice, move that many spaces, draw a card or cards, read them and d what the instruction tells you to do. Simple isn't it? Well, for developers it is not simple. The game is full of bugs and developers insist on working on new addons instead of correcting existing bugs. In other words - the game is not finished and really rushed and I need to point out it was released a long time ago. Too long for such issues to happen.

The game can freeze or crash just after loading it. I experienced game freeze on the main menu several times - solution, do not leave the game on the title screen or it will stop responding. You will be forced to start the game again and/or start Steam again, and/or reboot your system.
The game was not properly tested before release and it is more than obvious.
A lot of cards do not work as they are supposed to. Many card effects lead to a dead end as you will not be able to do anything (I see that problem with many spells while casted on other players). Example: after casting for example, Misfortune spell on the opponent, the game stopped responding and did not give any player any opportunity to make their moves, the game stops, the timeout counter freezes and you or any other player is forced to leave the game in order to make it move on.
Connection issues occur every game. Some players are kicked out of the server for no reason. Sometimes you cannot go back to the game you were playing.
After joining the server and starting or looking for a game, your game can stop responding, forcing you to reboot your game and ocassionally your Steam and/or your system.
Who put Quit button in the Settings? Standing ovation for the analysts/architects/developers and anyone responsible for this sensible chuckle design. I laughed, my friends laughed. Good comedy.
There is no way to speed up the game play. It goes very long and I played some games for such a long time that I do not recall any actual board games to last that long (and I played with 7 people at a time!). You have to wait for every action even if no action is available at the moment. For example: even though you have only one choice, the system does not automatically go with the only choice but waits for you to select it. Bad idea.
There is a number cards that do not work properly or do not work at all and when it comes tot he interaction betwen some cards, majority of such situations lead to a glitch, mostly forcing you to rejoin the game or restarting it.
Each new addon comes with a new set of bugs. Beware.
Random Number Generator is really poor and developers should think before they do something rigged as this. There is a chance that you will throw 1" for about 5-10 times in a row which is impossible if you were really rolling dice. This NEEDS to be fixed. I remember rolling the same set of numbers several times in a row. Bad development. There is no explanation for such bad execution of dice roll simulation.
You can be kicked out of the game without any chance (yes!) for coming back. The game tends to bug out and nothing can be done to go back to it. Progress is lost. The most disappointing.
Inviting your Steam friends is very buggy. I have never successfully invited anyone without a crash
date:
so I do not use that feature.


TL;DR - If you want to play the great game which is Talisman - go and buy the original board game
recommended: you will never have to reboot anything

reviewText:
Talisman is the classic adventure board game of powerful magic and ferocious creatures. Play as one of many classic fantasy archetypes such as an elf, wizard, monk, thief (and many more!) as you gain experience, powerful items/weapons, followers, spells and so on. Adventure around the board until you're ready to tackle the dreaded inner region, reach the Crown of Command, and claim victory!

If you like gameplay that is all about playing the odds, you'll probably enjoy yourself in Talisman. At first glance it seems like a simple roll-and-move game where the player has little control over what happens to them during any given turn, but it's actually very involved as winning requires understanding how to create good odds for yourself. It's also a game where you need to understand that bad things WILL happen and there's nothing you could've done about it; or even if you lost a fight you shoulda won - it's ok because 80% odds in your favor means you'll still lose 20% of the time.

Talisman is a very interesting mix of a laid back casual game (because of how simple any given turn is) and also a very cutthroat game. Players will clash in many PvP battles over the course of a game and powerful items will switch hands as players take them from each other through force or other means. You'll need to always take into account the other players, knowing which ones you should target and which ones will target you.

So if you like fantasy adventure and gameplay that's all about navigating the wims of random luck, I highly recommend Talisman. It's a light game that manages to capture that feeling of going on an epic quest and overcoming great challenges. There's a reason this game is still around despite many bigger and more involved adventure board games being released since the 80s, so play this digital adaptation and find out what makes Talisman so special.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A little bit too complex for its own good.   A game took me a good two hours with myself and three AI's, and you couldn't speed the AI turns up enough for my liking.  The second game was broken by an elf who spent the entire game teleporting between two forests, increasing their stats endlessley.  I would like to try the board game though.\n\nI played two more games to completion with 2 AI's, and the game is just way too random.  The frog mechanic can move a character from first to last place instantly, and sometimes there's nothing you can do to prevent it.  Getting the rolls you need to win is incredibly difficult, and once someone gets to the Crown of Power they almost always win.

reviewText:
2 Words: DLC marketplace. Its one thing when you have dlc in your game, its another when the minute I try to create a game I'm slammed in the face for not having 90% of the content available. This is most evident in the player selection where it shows you the 6 heroes you own and the 50+ that you do not in a hodgepodge of little icons with no labels.

Look, I can understand having DLC as a part of the game, but DLC constitutes almost 4 times what the base game has to offer. And if you really want to enjoy this game, its basically mandatory.

Avoid this marketing strategy and avoid this company. A 14.99 game should not feel like an incomplete experience and have dlc content that is pushed this heavily on its players. Expansions are fair, but DLC should not be required to enjoy the game nor be pushed as heavily.

reviewText:
This game is well-made, well-designed, but not worth it - even if it's on sale.

Along with most board games of this design (such as D&D) the designers only feigned giving their players the ability to develop sound strategies and some sense of control, when in reality, it's a crap shoot - so in that respect - if you don't like actual strategy games this isn't for you.

If you like games that crap on you when you're doing well - this is pretty good - the designers did keep the element of Life Happens" that goes along with board games of this type
date: allowing this much instability without crashing the game is pretty amazing though.\n\nIn summary
recommended: this is NOT a strategy game (as it was listed) - it is a pretty good rogue-like rpg

reviewText:
Not recommended for single player.

Played the demo through several games. Did not play multi-player only played single player.

Ran into game breaking problems with the AI in single player:

1.) AI is dumb as a rock. All it had to do was move foward to the command square and crush me. It was way overpowered from running around the board collecting loot/kill trophies but instead of attacking it continues to run around like a headless chicken. I sit at the crown square and roll one dice (d6, 1-3 no damage, 4-6 1 damage to all enemy) over and over and over and over....bleh Can't move out and I'm using a melee character so only option was rolling every round. I was actually hoping the AI would crush me to put me out of my missery but quit game and started another.

2.) There was a healer card on the board at the forest during one game. All other AI's dead from attrition by d6 crowning them. The elf can teleport from woods to woods so there I am rolling d6 at the crown square and the elf just keeps warping from woods to woods back and forth healing. That's it. It's a stalemate, unbreakable loop. I can't move, attack, nothing while the elf just teleports from the woods with healer to another woodland square than back again. Well played AI, you have defeated me with boredom.

Shut the game off and decided not to purchase after playing demo.

reviewText: I'm a lifelong board game fan, and bought Talisman: Digital Edition to see if I would like it well enough to purchase a tabletop copy for my collection.  Unfortunately, this digital edition has bugs and glitches that have kept me from finishing a game, primarily with AI getting stuck - unable to make a decision, and unable to force the AI to continue.  What I learned is that Talisman relies almost entirely on luck - rolling dice and drawing cards for everything.  Not enough strategy for my tastes.  And this digital edition still seems to have serious issues that make me not want to play, despite decent art and music.  If you like the fantasy theme, stick to the tabletop version, or try Descent: Journeys in the Dark instead.

reviewText:
My first gameplay...
Picked the Gambler.
Rolled low, went to Tavern. Got drunk, lost a turn.
My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Dragon with 7 strength that rolled a 6. Lost a life.
My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Craft 5 creature that rolled high. Lost a life.
My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Pig with 1 strength.
OMG.. I'm going to beat it. Pig rolled a 5. Beat me by one point. Lost a life.
Lost the game.

Beat by bacon. 10/10 Would lose to bacon again.

---------------------
UPDATE: The game can be fun.. but after finding out that all dice are predetermined at the beginning of the game I will not be recommending this and giving it a thumbs DOWN now. This is a ♥♥♥♥ poor mechanic and development choice for any developer. Why give people the illusion they are rolling a dice for random rolls if they are not truly random when thrown? Those times I'm feeling lucky and end up with those craptastic one's make me feel cheated since I now know they were picked when I started the game. Coding in a SIMPLE RNG routine for each roll is NOT that hard and actually would use less resources than storing up a predetermined roll chart. I know this because I AM a developer. You wanted to prevent people from reloading a game and possibly rolling a better RANDOM roll? **WRONG** The same principle can be used by that same person because they know what the next roll is going to be and they just reload and choose a different course or action. You haven't foiled their attempt to get ahead.

reviewText:
First off, unless I'm mistaken, this is my first Steam review. I hate that it's negative, but I am way too ticked off at this game NOT to give it a negative review. Second, this game makes me wish I had bought it AFTER the Stean refund policy change. I would refund this pile in a heartbeat. Now let me get into the things I hated about the game. Also, for the most part, you are not going to read anything here that are not in the other reviews. If you like the board game, you might like this if you don't crash. If not my gripes are similair to others

So, I bought this game a few months ago, but never got around to playing it. I left Neverwinter Nights, and get a pop-up saying if I buy a character for Talisman the profits with go to charity. Great! I love to help charity. And it is a shaman. Shamans and Druids are some of my favorite characters. So load up the game, and search the main page for a tutorial. There's none, which is troubling, but I figure, 'hey, it's probably a tutorial as you play kind of game'. Which it is. Problem is you ghave to choose your character with stats that you have NO CLUE what they do. So I do what I always do in a fantasy game where I'm not sure about the mechanics. I pick the Warrior, because it is almost aways the easiest class. I also make sure there is only one  opponent, because i wanted the make the game as easy as possiblee.

Then I get into the game. My first turn I roll, get a 6 move to the temple. My whole strategy tois to get the two weapons that the fighter can have, then play from there. I roll again, then have to fight an ape. I lose. No prob. It's the beginning of the game, and I can't expect to win every dice roll. Now I don't remember all my opponents turns, (partly because he was taking turns when I was reading text) but basically he didn't have ONE bad thing happen on any of his turns. So, I take my thirds turn and fight a creature with craft, and lose again. Next turn, roll again, got a dragon, lost again. Now mind you, you don't get a choice on whether to fight or not. Some classes give some choice in some situations, but mostly, roll and get blssed or f-d. So, I'm down 3 lives, and have some event where I lose ANOTHER LIFE! My opponent. Again, my opponent has lost no life, and hasn't even had to fight. I am a WARRIOR and I have won no fights. I just want a weapon. So I spend my one gold to get back 1 hp because I am at one HP. THEN I get the second gold that would have allowed me to get a weapon.  Then I roll a demon which I would have to roll a 6 to tie. So back to 1 hp. At this point I say F this game. So I want to see what happens when you die, so I attack the creature with craft (magic) because he should have an advantage. And THEN I win. *Faceplam*

Anyway I was done within 5 minutes of that. My opponent was already in the second ring. This game is JUST RANDOM LUCK. I own 600 on Steam, (though I've prob only played a little over 500 of them) and this will likely wind up on the bottom 50 of them.

reviewText:
My first gameplay...
Picked the Gambler.
Rolled low, went to Tavern. Got drunk, lost a turn.
My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Dragon with 7 strength that rolled a 6. Lost a life.
My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Craft 5 creature that rolled high. Lost a life.
My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Pig with 1 strength.
OMG.. I'm going to beat it. Pig rolled a 5. Beat me by one point. Lost a life.
Lost the game.

Beat by bacon. 10/10 Would lose to bacon again.

---------------------
UPDATE: The game can be fun.. but after finding out that all dice are predetermined at the beginning of the game I will not be recommending this and giving it a thumbs DOWN now. This is a ♥♥♥♥ poor mechanic and development choice for any developer. Why give people the illusion they are rolling a dice for random rolls if they are not truly random when thrown? Those times I'm feeling lucky and end up with those craptastic one's make me feel cheated since I now know they were picked when I started the game. Coding in a SIMPLE RNG routine for each roll is NOT that hard and actually would use less resources than storing up a predetermined roll chart. I know this because I AM a developer. You wanted to prevent people from reloading a game and possibly rolling a better RANDOM roll? **WRONG** The same principle can be used by that same person because they know what the next roll is going to be and they just reload and choose a different course or action. You haven't foiled their attempt to get ahead.

reviewText: I love the board game.  However, the board game is, frankly, a bit flawed.  Talisman, in a nutshell, is: roll a die, 1,2,3 bad, 4,5,6 good.  Repeat. and repeat... and repeat... and... well, keep going for two hours.  If you like Talisman, then get this bit of nostagia (yes, there are new versions of Talisman out, but really, the first edition was the best fun).  I don't like all the add on packs for such a primitive game.  I also do not recomend multi player for this game (it deserves to be played on a table).  Not for anyone who does not have experience with the board game.

reviewText:
Love it. I first played this board game when it came out in the 80's and loved it. I have played it several times since with various expansions and seeing it come to life digitally brought back so many memories.
It is practically identical to the original board game, and does have a few annoying bugs (mostly around spells not quite activating the way they should) but outside of that this is a really well done port of the original.

It is just as unbalanced as the original board game but the runestones go a small way to helping that out, bringing the weaker characters into the mix nicely.

Recommended and looking forward to all the future expansions. Bring on the dungeon!

reviewText: This is a faithful re-creation of Talisman the boardgame, and that's its problem.  Talisman is a dreadfully prolonged lesson on the fate of die rolls, which will see you endlessly sliding back and forth until you luck out and roll whatever number you needed, which will push you toward the end game, until, of course, a single unlucky die roll sends you spinning back to square one and adds 90 more minutes onto the play time of this terrible, outdated game.  I suppose if you like the original treadmill of futility that is Talisman, you'll like this game, too.

reviewText: Plays really slow. Compared to Talisman: Prologue, I would say just buy whichever is on sale. Both have slow interfaces and annoying control methods. reviewText:
Gave up in disgust.  The devs for this game had two jobs:

1:  Design a AI for solo play.

2:  Design a UI that allows players to play an already existing board game on the PC.

The devs failed so spectacularly at #2 that playing a game I loved became an exercise in frustration.  I am not exaggerating when I say that making this game a browser/mobile game would have been an improvement, as the developers would be forced to conform to standard UI conventions.

For example, nstead of Enter to accept prompts, the keybind is Space.. what?  Why can't I exit out of my active window with Escape?  Why does it always send me to the Main Menu?  And of course, I can't change the keybinds!  Borderless Windowed Mode?  Lol.  Run in higher resolution?  HAHAHAHA.

When I say that the devs had two jobs, I mean it - all art assets are lifted from the board game in 2D format.  The Help function directs players to their site with a wonky search function.  Nothing like seeing format code while browsing the site with Firefox.  Real quality, that.  All of this makes enduring the awful UI especially galling.  I'm done with this game.

reviewText:
This game is fun, but only if you have the correct mindset: sit back in your chair and relax, maybe pop a beer and most of all, play with your friends and socialize. The randomness makes it really hard to have control of the game and it can be infuriating to spend half an hour to try to move into a specific space that is necessary in order to move forward towards winning the game. Another thing to keep in mind is that a single game takes several hours to complete.

The game gets pretty dull already after one game and I really recommend that you invest in some DLC in order to make it more interesting. A good starting point is to buy the Highlands expansion and The Dungeon Expansion and if you want to live dangeroulsy: the Reaper expansion.  If you want to shorten the game length (and don't want to grind) it might be a good idea to buy the Runestone deck. I've never tried any of the DLC that modifies the victory condition, so keep that in mind if you listen to my recommendations.

I've played the tabletop version of this game and have about 10 hours of in game time divided on two Steam accounts at the time of writing this review.

Now to the implementation: the game is extremely buggy. You can play  a whole game without issues, but it gets really irritating when the bugs appear. All cards don't work as they should and during my last game we had to restart it twice because we were unable to do any actions. The AI is stupid and I don't recommend this game if you plan to play it alone offline.

So do I recommend this game? Although it's glitchy it's not unplayable. It's fun with the right people and it's an OK way to waste some time, but it's really not for everyone. So yes, if you are OK with all the downsides I stated I think that it's a good buy!

reviewText:
I recommend the digital implementation of this game over the board game, but I do not recommend Talisman over other digital board games.

Odds are good that, if you're looking at buying the Digital Edition, you know what Talisman is all about. As a board game, I don't think it is very good. But, I do think that this digital implementation makes it playable.

So, if you know you want to play Talisman, this is the way to go.
If you're thinking about getting this because it's a much cheaper way to explore the board game, this is the way to go.

If you've stumbled across this game and you're hoping for a really enjoyable experience and you don't know what you're getting into, you probably will not enjoy this game.

Granted it IS a fairly done rendition of the board game, but lack of added features combined with difficulty of certain things in-game that are easy to do in real life (like just taking a closer look at a particular area) make this less than a stellar pick. reviewText:
People who like Talisman the board game will like this digital recreation. It's spot on.

If you've never played talisman, it's a mediocre board game that often drags near the end of the game, with punishing mechanics that can wipe hours of play at the drop of a hat. I'd get the expansions and use the alternate endings to reduce the long end game.

That said, I've played this game and the physical version several times and keep coming back. Something about watching your character grow and overcoming challenges is addicting despite the dated board game mechanics.

reviewText: Not a very fun game unless you enjoy praying to RNGesus. I played my first and last game against the AI to learn how the game works. Meanwhile, the AI jerked around in the outer ring of tiles healing up at least as must damage I was dealing from the crown.\n\nWhile sitting through this mind-numbing experience I found that you can set house rules" to end the game when someone reaches the crown
date: or to stop healing when someone is at the crown
recommended: but the fact that there are such glaring design flaws in the base game is pretty unforgivable."

reviewText:
It’s unfortunate but Talisman is regrettably too feature starved to recommend.

And it’s not the expansions being individually sold, as that’s how the tabletop game is presented – it’s the awful connection issues, the inability to save an online game (you can resume the last game played online and those who played may reconnect, but that limits you to one game on the go), the bare minimum of the interface being explained (Counterspell must be queued up – ie; cast before the spell you’d like to prevent – because…because I don’t know) and the like.  Players can’t view the board spaces and the cards on it on another players turn.  And the AI (which can be played with in a multiplayer game to add players to the game) isn’t really competitive.  It doesn’t try to “win” the game.

Now, the good is it’s pretty faithful to the boardgame, and when it works and everyone remains connected it’s a pretty good way to scratch that itch. But the constant interruptions just drag the game on. It's a shame.

reviewText:
Spend your time with RNG.
Also, crash a lot in multiplayer.
A lot.

Granted it IS a fairly done rendition of the board game, but lack of added features combined with difficulty of certain things in-game that are easy to do in real life (like just taking a closer look at a particular area) make this less than a stellar pick.  As a recreation of the board game, not the worst.  But as a computer game overall, not good.

I don't regret the money I spent on this, but I *really* cannot recommend this unless you're a fan of the board game. If you are a fan of the board game, pick it up; you can typically find a game at least on Europe server (and you can easily see different servers for different areas of the world and switch between them), though you will crash, you *can* rejoin so it's not the end of the world.

reviewText:
This does the board  game version a lot of justice.
The cards and squares are accurate, the art is the same and the gameplay is fluid.
There have been some issues with crashes which I expect to be resolved soon and during the AI or other people turns you are unable to look at other squares of the board to become more familiar, but these issues are very little.
The AI does tend to make some silly choices that most people would try avoid but I imagine this will be patched soon
Overall 4/5

+Accurate when compared to the board game
+Fast and Fluent gameplay
+Soundtrack
+Saves your game

-A Few bugs
-No Tutorial for new players

voteText: captures the sheer fun of Talisman
helpfulPercent: Isn't that why we play games
votesHelpful: for fun?\n\nA few negative reviews commented on the woeful AI. But
votesTotal: perhaps these folk are playing the prelude titled Talisman: Prologue. I have found the AI to be pretty good. And let's not forget that Talisman is largely a luck based game. All of the so-called tactics I have seen and heard about the game must still bow to the capriciousness of the deity known as RNG; even an AI like Deep Blue cannot predict the vagaries of dice rolls.\n\nThere are a few issues that linger. One of the most annoying is when an AI opponent draws an event card. Unless you are a speed reader or you know every Talisman card by rote - and with all of the expansions in the physical boardgame there is an insane number of cards
votesFunny:
you won't have time to read what the event is. You have to zoom in on the board section where the event is. The same holds true for other non-spell cards. This has been brought up to the devs but as yet there has been no fix for this.

The digital version allows you to earn runes which grant advatages in gameplay. [AI also collects these as well]. I like the mechanic as it lends a sort of leveling up feeling.

The Dungeon Expansion is next up and I cannot wait for its release! If it is as faithful as the physical version of the game
commentsCount:
it's going to be a blast.

I think that Talisman Digital Edition is a wonderful introduction to the fun world of tabletop boardgaming and it scratches the itch of tabletop boardgamers who want to play without the crazy setup and rather forced solo variants for the physical game found round the interwebz.

This is a STEAL at the price and I would advise buyers to spend a little extra dosh and get The Reaper and Frostmarch expansions as they add considerably to the game.

I hope that more boardgames experience a digital conversion. Are you listening Games Workshop and Fantasy Flight?

EDIT: 18 November. The Dungeon expansion really ramps this game up considerably. The AI can be quite nasty and that's good as Talisman is a cut throat game.

I am hopeful that the devs will release Blood Moon and The Dragon next. These two expansions literally change the game
column16: adding a bit more unpredictability to a game that can punch you in the face already and have you smiling about it.\n\nUPDATE January 15: Ya gota love this developer. reviewText:
Gave up in disgust.  The devs for this game had two jobs:

1:  Design a AI for solo play.

2:  Design a UI that allows players to play an already existing board game on the PC.

The devs failed so spectacularly at #2 that playing a game I loved became an exercise in frustration.  I am not exaggerating when I say that making this game a browser/mobile game would have been an improvement, as the developers would be forced to conform to standard UI conventions.

For example, nstead of Enter to accept prompts, the keybind is Space.. what?  Why can't I exit out of my active window with Escape?  Why does it always send me to the Main Menu?  And of course, I can't change the keybinds!  Borderless Windowed Mode?  Lol.  Run in higher resolution?  HAHAHAHA.

When I say that the devs had two jobs, I mean it - all art assets are lifted from the board game in 2D format.  The Help function directs players to their site with a wonky search function.  Nothing like seeing format code while browsing the site with Firefox.  Real quality, that.  All of this makes enduring the awful UI especially galling.  I'm done with this game.

reviewText:
As a little boy I was always curious about the Talisman boardgame. Now it came to Steam and on a sale I took my chances.

Pros:
+ Great art & figures just like the boardgame.
+ Long game time (depends how you look at it)
+ Various characters to choose from, each with their own special skill(s)
+ Some interessing items, followers & spells to get or sites to visit

Cons:
- To much depends on the lucky dice rolls
- Because of the dice rolls, the game can drag on and on, even if you have the Staff of Command
- Long game time (depends how you look at it)
- Imbalances on character front. A thief has 100% chance to Steal from you, even if you are the most powerful character on the board. It would be more interessing and more fair that the victim is able to save and hurt the thief when caught. Same for a sorceress with Beguile.
- Did I already say it depends to much on the lucky dice rolls?

Personally, I enjoyed it first but later on the myriad of (un)lucky dice rolls, character imbalances & to long game times diminished my enjoyment rapidly. I would rather spend my time on other games where I have much more controle at the games progress - and I have to blame my own stupidity - than on the sheer luck of a dice roll.

If they do some tweaking to give your chosen character a fairer chance/saving roll against some odds, I might take another look at it and change my mind about it . . .

reviewText:
As a little boy I was always curious about the Talisman boardgame. Now it came to Steam and on a sale I took my chances.

Pros:
+ Great art & figures just like the boardgame.
+ Long game time (depends how you look at it)
+ Various characters to choose from, each with their own special skill(s)
+ Some interessing items, followers & spells to get or sites to visit

Cons:
- To much depends on the lucky dice rolls
- Because of the dice rolls, the game can drag on and on, even if you have the Staff of Command
- Long game time (depends how you look at it)
- Imbalances on character front. A thief has 100% chance to Steal from you, even if you are the most powerful character on the board. It would be more interessing and more fair that the victim is able to save and hurt the thief when caught. Same for a sorceress with Beguile.
- Did I already say it depends to much on the lucky dice rolls?

Personally, I enjoyed it first but later on the myriad of (un)lucky dice rolls, character imbalances & to long game times diminished my enjoyment rapidly. I would rather spend my time on other games where I have much more controle at the games progress - and I have to blame my own stupidity - than on the sheer luck of a dice roll.

If they do some tweaking to give your chosen character a fairer chance/saving roll against some odds, I might take another look at it and change my mind about it . . .

reviewText:
This is a faithful recreation of a board game which involves running in circles and cursing dice rolls.

Its enjoyable but there are several aspects which may result in depression or rage.

Game summery:
- Choose a fantasy class (with stats and powers).
- Move randomly around the board and deal with events and other players.
- Increase your strength and/or craft skills.
- Fight your way to the center of the board.
- Patiently wait until everyone else dies. This can be reduced by changing the game options.

Be warned, this game contains:
- My average game length is 1-2 hours, but it can be much longer.
- Devastating random events. A single die roll MAY (and will) destroy you.
- Horribly broken AI (which gives you a fighting chance of victory).
- Waiting on AI turns (sometimes their turns are longer than your own).
- Predetermined dice rolls (no restarting to cheat against the AI).
- Lots of Confirm" buttons when several could be replaced by having an "undo" button instead.
- No "auto play" option for times when there is no choice involved.
- Massive amounts of pay DLC.

I recommend it
date: but its certainly not for everyone!"

reviewText:
DISREGARD THE METACRITIC SCORE...IT'S OBSOLETE

I got this game, season pass and the Shaman character. After my first full hour, I was hooked. I didn’t know or understand all the nuances or anything, as even at the time of this review, I’m still a novice (only 22.5 hours played and at level 3). But I can’t begin to express to you my enjoyment of this game.

I pick a random character and play. No game ever plays the same way twice and no one knows what they’re in for once they reach the pinnacle. The developers have really made a clean and engaging game here and continue to do so. I hate the word ‘fun’, but the fun factor in this game is through the roof. It doesn’t even resemble a ‘card’ game once you get started.

Final verdict: 8:10

reviewText:
This is a great game, I never heard of Talisman until i saw my friends playing the steam version, and I now play it almost once a week if not more with them. I would reccommend this game to anyone who just wants to have a good time with friends, but if youre looking for good gameplay on your own... unless you really just want some nostalgia This game isn't for you.

Pros
--------------
-Good time waster with friends
-nostalgic for you long time Talisman players
-interesting interactions
-you can laugh at the horrible AI

Cons
--------------
-Horribly buggy at times... many of which are game breaking (for example followers or spells that let you choose what your reroll will be will often reroll your second dice if you have 2 to choose from, or if you visit a shop and dont have enough money for an item the game just doesnt know what to do and breaks)
-purely based on RNG very few times is decision making or skill going to win you the game because 90% of this game is pure luck unless you get some crazy powerful items from some of the expansions (cough cough clockwork owl) or if you get characters that can see the top of the deck like sage or spy.
-kinda already stated as a pro but the AI is horrible, some might see that as a good thing because they can give you good items for bad ones or engage in battles they clearly cant win or dont use some items because they forget to... but otherwise its kinda stupid
-DLC for the game can be pretty pricey, if you buy the game and all expansions (not including the standalone characters) currently available it will go for roughly $45 or you can make it $75 and buy the season pass which includes all current and future DLC except one that was sold for charity.

TL;DR: The game is great to hang out with friends especially if you cant get together im person easily (or at all) But if you want everything its gonna be quite the money drop, the game is also horribly buggy and seems to lack some quality of life features like cancel buttons for most actions (shopping or spell casting for example) but if you can get past the bugs and horrible AI, then its a good time with your friends guarenteed!

reviewText:
Roll and move now on a PC.
Talisman: Digital edition is a PC implementation of tabletop board game Talisman. In it you will take a role of one of many adventures and embark on an adventure. Roll dice to move, pick a direction and deal with the consequences. Many characters have special powers that you can utilize in one way or another to make achieving your goals a bit quicker. Talisman came out a long time and as many old games it has it’s share of issues that modern board games have learned to deal with. However like old games it also has a big fan base.
Talisman: Digital edition is for better or worse a faithful representation of the board game. But as digital board games go it is quite well done. You are able to save your progress without occupying a whole table. You can play with your friends that are spread across the globe. And you can play by yourself if you don’t have any friends to play it. If you buy season pass that gives you access to all the dlc, of which Talisman has many, it will save you quite a bit of shelf space as well.
Most of the issues with Talisman: Digital edition come inherited from the board game. That means it can take forever to finish a game and is quite unbalanced and a lot depends on a roll of a die. Added to that are a few AI issues where computer controlled players can get stuck in a loop of selling and buying swords or make actions that are not quite optimal.
Dad rating: Fine
You can save only on your turn. But you can pause the game during computer opponent turn.
Some of the art on some cards can be a bit scary but it’s always static images that you could see in a book or a board game.Talisman is not my favorite board game. But I do like board games and it’s good to see some of them cross over to PC world. With digital implementation of board games they usually fall short because playing with physical components is so much better. In Talisman: Digital edition a lot of the hassle of playing with real board game is removed and that’s why I recommend it.

reviewText: This game will make you completely distrust computer dice rolls. Also, change the setting to allow swapping out quests on the Warlock's Cave spot (it is disabled by default), otherwise you can get the quest to damage a character, and all the other characters are on the inner row, or at the Crown of Command, and you get to waste a half hour waiting for the dice rolls to kill you.\nThat being said, it was a fun game (albeit a bit long) but they give you the options to minimize some of the pain, and to at least give yourselves a quicker death than the long death the dice promise you.

reviewText:
Amazing game!

I got the game in July 2014 on a sweat -50% season pass. BEST DECISION OF MY LIFE! The amount of content added to this game is epic. I am a huge fan of randomness and replay ability and this game is perfect! No two games are alike and you have a lot of options to customize the speed and difficulty of the game.

You might not be a fan of dice games because too much luck is involved, honestly so am I! I rarely play dice games, but I feel that talisman has the perfect combination of luck-to-strategy ratio. I like to compare it to real life. In real life, no matter how cautious you are, no matter how safe your daily routine is, on a particularly unlucky day... you can die... at the prime of your life you can get hit by a car... you can go to the hospital for routine surgery and die on the table... Talisman is like that!

One minute you are the terror of the board, banishing demons and slaying dragons with the flick of your wand or tap of your sword, the next minute you are a cursed toad, powerless and vulnerable. The other night I lost a game after a series of 3 unlucky dice rolls, I was in the lead on stats, two turns away from winning the game, next turn I was dead. The odds of me dyeing there were 0.4%. I wasn't even mad, that was amazing!

Good things can happen as well. One game I was the underdog, a lowly merchant, unskilled in combat, unwise in magic. After gathering a small pose consisting of a gnome, a guide and a faery; and armed with only a Talisman and a four leaf clover. I managed to pick the lock on the portal of power, brave the forgotten depths of the lost mines, escape a vampire's domain (RIP followers), then defeat four lesser demons in combat, cross the valley of fire and finally arrive at the crown of command. There, I obtained the power to command death as my servant and send him to kill my enemies one by one! All this was achieved with beginner level stats. I had no chance to win by overtaking my enemies the safe way so I risked it all, and this time I won.

I have no problem finding games online to play with strangers. It's more fun to play with friends. I regularly buy copies of Talisman when it's on sale (usually 1-2 euro for the base game) and gift them. The good thing is that my friends don't need the expansions to play with me, because in a multiplayer game if one person has all the expansions then the game is played with all of them. In my experience games with 3 players are the best. With 4 or more the game tends to last longer. Two player games are also fine.

The rules of the game are easy on beginners. Even if it's a complex game, the rules come at you one at a time. You don't need to know what all the cards in the game do, because you will only draw one or two cards a turn usually and then just read those cards and see what happens! I remember when I first played Talisman, I had no idea what was happening... and that was great! I'm a dwarf in a fantasy world. I fight monsters, find treasure, and buy drinks at the tavern. My opponent is a troll who found a unicorn. The unicorn is smarter than he is...

I could say a lot more about this game, it is simply amazing and lots of fun. It's well worth full price, if you are undecided, buy the base game on sale and play it online. You will not regret it!

reviewText:
This is a report, more so then a review.

I really love this game, but, I think some people cheat on it.
For example, I just finished a game that looked like someone had a dice roll hack.
Since almost the start of the game All I had to do was land on one character contolled by an internet user.
I had a spell that would of immeiatley cost them two lives. Thus I would've won.
No matter what I rolled i never landed on them.
They never rolled one bad die throughout the game. Not one!
In my knowledge of probbability, thats near impossible.
Its certanly immprobable.
Some people are gonna say I'm a sore loser.
Quite the contrary.
I lost several games in a row and enjoyed them all. Cuz it seemed random dice rolls werer been made.
But this last game seemed like a hack.
I was determined to beat the hacker, but of course, thats impossible.

Anyway, the game is great if you like board games. And if there is no cheaters.
I recommend buy this if you are into fantasy games.

I would love if they brought out hero quest the board game. Now that I would definitely buy
